I found several scholarly articles analyzing Brave New World through a Foucauldian lens, particularly focusing on biopower, disciplinary systems, and surveillance in the novel. Here's what the search revealed:

## Foucauldian Analysis of Brave New World

The search results show extensive academic work applying Michel Foucault's theories to Aldous Huxley's *Brave New World* (1932). Scholars describe the novel as "a nightmarish depiction of a post-human world where human beings are mass-produced to serve production and consumption."

### Biopower and Disciplinary Control

Researchers discuss "the manipulations of minds and bodies with reference to Foucault's biopower and disciplinary systems that make the citizens of the world state more profitable and productive."(no content)The goal of such a disciplinary society, according to Foucault, "is to make citizens more profitable and productive, and less individual, through mental and physical conditioning in order to turn people into compliant subjects."

### Mechanisms of Control

Scholars argue that "Brave New World depicts a dystopian systematic control of mind and body through eugenic engineering, biological conditioning, hypnopaedia, sexual satisfaction, and drugs so as to keep the worldians completely controlled, collectivized and contented in a totalitarian society."

### Elimination of Resistance

The analysis shows how "the world state eradicates love, religion, art and history and deploys language devoid of any emotions and thoughts to control the mind that judges and decides."(no content)Researchers note that the novel "anticipates the Foucauldian paradigm of resistance, subversion and containment, ending in eliminating the forces that pose a challenge to the ideology of the world state."

### Panopticon and Surveillance

The research connects Foucault's concept of the Panopticon to the novel, noting how "surveillance exercised over the prisoners disciplines them inside the institution."(no content)Scholars observe that "system of panopticon power does not only limit to the prison" but "is apparent in numerous social structures such as hospitals, schools, and workshop" where "discipline exercised over these places is a type of power."

### Docile Bodies

The analysis employs Foucauldian terms to show how "the world state works 'to discipline the body, optimize its capabilities, exhort its forces, increase its usefulness and docility, integrate it into systems of efficient and economic controls'" to "produce the docile bodies that follow the dictates of the world state."

This body of scholarship demonstrates how *Brave New World* serves as a literary representation of Foucault's theories about modern power structures, surveillance, and the production of compliant subjects in disciplinary societies.
